title: As record snowfall continues, more California resorts extend their ski seasons
text:
As record snowfall continues, more California resorts extend their ski seasons 
February 22, 2017 By Robert Pursell 
With the West Coast continuing to receive a massive amount of snowfall this season, Vail Resorts announced Wednesday in a press release that two of its resorts in the Lake Tahoe area — Heavenly and Northstar — will be extending their scheduled closing days by at least a week this year: A post shared by Heavenly Mountain Resort (@skiheavenly) on Feb 22, 2017 at 10:59am PST 
Per its announcement, Heavenly and Northstar will both extend their seasons past their initial scheduled closing day of April 16. Heavenly Mountain Resort will be open daily for the week of April 16-23 and then again on the weekend of April 28-30. Northstar California will be open daily from April 16-23. 
RELATED: California buried under the most snow it has seen in 22 years 
Vail’s third property in the Tahoe region — Kirkwood Mountain Resort— has not changed its scheduled closing day yet. 
“We’re thrilled to offer guests great skiing and riding, as well as a variety of spring activities for visitors this spring at Heavenly and Northstar,” Pete Sonntag, the senior vice president and chief operating officer of Heavenly Mountain Resort, said in the press release. “With the record snowfall totals in January and continued snowfall throughout the season, we’re excited to offer guests an unparalleled experience at the mountains.” A heavenly employee tasked with the unenviable job of clearing a historic amount of snow. Photo: Courtesy of Heavenly 
The announcement comes on the heels of yet another huge storm dumped snow around Lake Tahoe. 
Per Fox 31 , a seven-day storm that ended Wednesday dumped around seven feet of snow at many Tahoe ski resorts. Heavenly reported receiving 80 inches during that stretch. 
Per the Tahoe Daily Tribune , all three Vail Resorts properties are currently in the midst of their snowiest season on record. 
First Tracks reports the record snowfall totals isn’t just limited to Vail Resorts’ properties, but fairly common in the Tahoe area this season. Mount Rose Ski Tahoe on the Nevada side of North Lake Tahoe has already received a staggering 636 inches this season, breaking its record for snowiest year to date: A post shared by Mt. Rose (@mtroseskitahoe) on Feb 22, 2017 at 10:38am PST 
And further south in California, resorts are also having banner years. 
Mammoth Mountain currently has the biggest base depth in the U.S. with a gargantuan 350-inch base at its summit, and has now pulled down 510 inches of snow at its Main Lodge on the season, marking the first time since 2010-2011 the mountain has crossed the 400-inch threshold: A post shared by Mammoth Mountain (@mammothmountain) on Feb 22, 2017 at 11:28am PST 
“The 2016-17 season at Mammoth has delivered with over 42 feet of snow and no end in sight,” Lauren Burke, the public relations manager for Mammoth, told GrindTV. “There is a huge storm in the forecast this weekend and with well over four months of season left, we could be breaking even more records — we’re coming for the total season snowfall record of 668 inches in 2010-2011.” 
Mammoth has already announced they will be open until at least July 4 . 
Per the press release from Vail Resorts, this is the biggest snowpack the state of California has seen in 22 years.
